findings.title: Attackers could mint more Fertilizer than intended due to an unused variable
findings.description: Due to an unused local variable, an attacker could mint more Fertilizer than should be allowed by the sale.

findings.title: Lack of a two-step process for ownership transfer
findings.description: The lack of a two-step process for transferring contract ownership can lead to permanent misconfiguration of the system if the wrong address is mistakenly provided.

findings.title: Possible underflow could allow more Fertilizer than MAX_RAISE to be minted
findings.description: If the amount of Fertilizer purchased reaches MAX_RAISE (i.e., 77 million), an attacker could cause the remaining() function to underflow, allowing the sale to continue indefinitely.

findings.title: Risk of Fertilizer id collision that could result in loss of funds
findings.description: If a user mints Fertilizer tokens twice during two different seasons, the same token `id` for both tokens could be calculated, and the first entry will be overridden; if this occurs and the

findings.title: The sunrise() function rewards callers only with the base incentive
findings.description: The increasing incentive is calculated and included in emitted logs but not actually applied to the number of Bean tokens rewarded to users who call sunrise()

findings.title: Solidity compiler optimizations can be problematic
findings.description: Beanstalk has enabled optional compiler optimizations in Solidity, which have been known to cause security implications due to optimization bugs.

findings.title: Lack of support for external transfers of nonstandard ERC20 tokens
findings.description: The `TokenFacet` contract does not properly handle external transfers of nonstandard ERC20 tokens via the `transferFrom` operation, potentially leading to users being unaware of failed token transfers.

findings.title: Plot transfers from users with allowances revert if the owner has an existing pod listing
findings.description: Whenever a plot transfer is executed by a user with an allowance (i.e., a transfer in which the caller was approved by the plot’s owner), the transfer will revert if there is an existing listing for the pods contained in that plot.

findings.title: Users can sow more Bean tokens than are burned
findings.description: The protocol allows users to partially fill the amount of Bean tokens and still sow the full amount, leading to a discrepancy between the number of tokens burned and sown.

findings.title: Pods may never ripen
findings.description: During periods of decreasing demand, the pod line can grow indefinitely and pods may never ripen, causing lenders to receive an unappealing time-weighted rate of return.

findings.title: Bean and the offer backing it are strongly correlated
findings.description: The demand for holding Bean tokens at present and the demand for receiving Bean tokens in the future are strongly correlated, introducing reflexive risk.

findings.title: Ability to whitelist assets uncorrelated with Bean price, misaligning governance incentives
findings.description: Stalk holders can deposit whitelisted assets without strong correlation to Bean's price, which could lead to misaligned governance incentives and potential financial losses for the protocol.

findings.title: Unchecked burnFrom return value
findings.description: The burnFrom function does not check its return value, allowing an attacker to drain the contract's balance of underlying tokens.

findings.title: The token is not upgradeable.
findings.description: Upgradeable contracts may change their rules over time.

findings.title: The owner has limited minting capabilities.
findings.description: Malicious or compromised owners can abuse minting capabilities.

findings.title: The token is not pausable.
findings.description: The smart contract does not have a mechanism to pause the token, which can lead to potential security risks if an issue arises.

findings.title: The owner cannot blacklist the contract.
findings.description: Malicious or compromised owners can trap contracts relying on tokens with a blacklist. Identify blacklisting features by hand.
